title: 107_hr502
content: The Act may be cited as the "Caribbean Regional Assistance Act of 2001". It includes findings related to the Caribbean region. The Congress finds that the Caribbean region is a vital "third border" for the United States due to its proximity and importance as a tourist destination. Issues such as unemployment, weak judicial systems, environmental degradation, and natural disasters in the region directly impact the well-being of the United States. The public sector in many Caribbean countries lacks training and efficiency, leading to economic growth lagging behind Latin America in the 1990s. Highly trained labor is often unavailable in the region. (5) Highly trained labor is scarce in the Caribbean region due to governmental red tape hindering private sector opportunities in the global marketplace. (6) Reliance on a few exports and tourism, along with high transportation and telecommunication costs, limits growth. (7) Developing a regional corporate strategy is crucial for business success and global competition. (8) Small Caribbean countries face economic stress from declining banana production and potential loss of EU trade preferences. (9) Economic displacement of small farmers and supporting infrastructure workers is ongoing in some countries. The workforce in Caribbean countries faces added pressures on their economies as they strive for growth and competitiveness in the global market. Economic, social, and political challenges in the region have led to increased crime and illegal immigration to the United States. The United States is also concerned about narcotics trafficking and is working with Caribbean governments on drug interdiction and money laundering. The development of the Caribbean region relies on the efficiency and fairness of its legal systems, which are perceived as inefficient. The legal systems in the Caribbean region are inefficient and ineffective, needing improvement in the administration of law and quality of justice. The ecosystems supporting the region's economies are under severe stress due to environmental problems like inadequate waste management and land use practices. The Caribbean region has the second-highest HIV/AIDS prevalence rate globally, with the epidemic spreading rapidly in some countries. The Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act was enacted in 1983 to encourage democratic governments and revitalized economies in the Caribbean region. In May 1997, US and Caribbean leaders pledged to strengthen cooperation in responding to future challenges. The Bridgetown Barbados Summit committed the US and Caribbean countries to a Plan of Action in trade, economic development, and justice and security. In April 1998, Western Hemisphere leaders emphasized the benefits of open trade and market-based policies in the Americas. The United States aims to complete the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA) process by 2005 to expand markets for goods and services and ensure safe destinations for foreign investment. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new chapter focusing on providing assistance for the Caribbean region to promote economic development, diversification, technical training, trade enhancement, judicial reform, and environmental management. The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to establish and carry out a program to support these activities. Activities supported under section 499O include improving governmental institutions in the Caribbean region by providing technical assistance, training for customs services, revenue collection, and investment promotion. It also involves specialized training for judges, economic diversification efforts, and coordination of administrative procedures. The curr_chunk focuses on providing technical assistance and training to countries in the Caribbean region to develop regional business strategies, increase lending assistance to small enterprises, promote compliance with international trade agreements, boost the tourism industry, and diversify the agricultural sector. The curr_chunk focuses on improving environmental management, HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment in the Caribbean region. The curr_chunk discusses credit assistance for economic and development activities under a specific program, with reference to general provisions applicable to development credit authority. The curr_chunk defines the countries of the Caribbean region and HIV/AIDS. It also authorizes appropriations for a specific program. "Authorization of $8,000,000 for fiscal years 2002-2006 for chapter purposes. USAID office in Caribbean region established for Foreign Assistance Act. Report requirement." The Administrator of USAID must submit a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment, outlining a plan to implement chapter 13 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for the Caribbean region. The plan should include key objectives, actions needed to achieve them, benchmarks for progress, and how the objectives align with the Act. The curr_chunk discusses how the objectives outlined in the report relate to the overall US objectives for the Western Hemisphere and worldwide. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined as specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate.
